clues.text: Occurring twice a year
A judge who winks at the prosecution & glares at the defense is showing this
Geographic description of a firm with offices in L.A. & New York
Term used of your first premolar
An expression such as 5x + 3y
This underwear brand owns the first American trademark ever used for textiles
In slang, "scraping" this is reaching for something of the lowest quality
The Latin legal phrase amicus curiae means this
Neville Chamberlain & Winston Churchill both served as this Senior Finance Minister
This Catholic sacrament was long known as extreme unction
A coquette is a flirtatious woman; insert 1 letter to get this deep-fried cake of meat
Accouchement is the time surrounding this major life event
Originally the forward part of an army, this hyphenated word now refers to any radical innovator
A moue is a dissatisfied pursing of the lips, the equivalent of this, which also has "ou" in the middle
Meaning uninterested, it's the past participle of a French word meaning "to become boring"
This border river also called Rio Bravo empties into the Gulf of Mexico
The Meuse River separates Belgium & this country from Maastricht to Maaseik
This river is on the border of Germany & Switzerland
The Usumacinta River forms the border between Mexico & this country
The Torne River is on the border of Sweden & this country until it empties in the Gulf of Bothnia
This English captain called his 1587 raid on Cadiz, destroying much of the Armada, "singeing the King of Spain's Beard"
Enduring into the 20th Century, this last Chinese Imperial Dynasty is also called the Qing
This organization includes countries that spent centuries fighting, but it won the 2012 Nobel Peace Prize
In 597 B.C., this Babylonian king captured Jerusalem & took 18-year-old King Jehoaichin back to Babylon as a captive
In 1961 Algerians began training rebels from this West African colony who wanted independence from the Portuguese

clues.text: When the sun is directly overhead at the Tropic of Cancer on June 20 or 21, we are experiencing the summer this
Best seen high overhead in summer, the constellation of this strong guy had a star go nova in 1934
"Fun" being a relative term, in 2012 Joey Chestnut downed 68 of these to win a contest held at Coney Island every July 4
The athletic, piping & dancing competitions held in Scotland every summer are known as these "games"
The production of plays in summer by a repertory company; it's the title of a Judy Garland film

clues.text: "Is not tomorrow, boy, the Ides of March?"

"Prospero my lord shall know what I have done...
so king, go safely on to seek thy son"
"You lie, in faith, for you are called plain Kate, and bonny Kate, and sometimes Kate the curst"
"He's coming hither; now i' the night, i' the haste, and Regan with him"
"...at least into a jealousy so strong that judgment cannot cure"
Phosphenes are the sensations of light you get when pressure is applied to these
Wamble is a term for the sound this organ can make
Brannock is the name of the device that measures these from widths of 3A to 3E
It can describe an actor who's over the top, or be slang for a muscle at the back of the leg
When used normally, a garrote fits snugly around this part of the victim's body
"at" often follows this word, also the name of a comic book company
The U.S. used the military doctrine of "shock &" this, an overwhelming feeling of reverence
Change one letter in "wonder" & you get this synonym, meaning to consider thoughtfully
It brings on a feeling of wonder when it precedes "party" & "symphony"
This "-ish"y word is from the Latin for "to strike with thunder"
"The Wizard of Menlo Park" by Randall Stross tells how this man "invented the modern world"
"The Man & The Secrets" is Curt Gentry's take on the life of this longtime government official
Taking a line from a Supremes hit, James Haskins' "I'm Gonna Make You Love Me" is about this Motown star
Lois Scharf's biography of this 20th century woman is subtitled "First Lady of American Liberalism"
The 1974 biography "Mr. Lincoln's Camera Man" brought this photographer into focus

rounds.text: In a 1967 novel this Nobel Prize winner wrote, "The secret of a good old age is simply an honorable pact with solitude"
